response: The way these lawyers talk. Well, it makes you crazy. They seemed to have a good case for the guy's guilt. Finger prints on the trigger and all.
But I look at that guy and I just can't see it.
I figure I can size up any man with enough time. And given that I've spend enough time in this goddamn court room to last me a lifetime, I just can't figure that man as a killer.
Evidence bein' what it is, he's probably guilty. But something about him gives me pause.
What a damn shame, a woman that pretty ending up with a fate like that.
A stuffy law man if I ever saw one.
Maybe he deserved a good punch in the face.

Man, I've been all 'round this country. And in my travels I've seen every manner of stuffy law man thinking he's a big shot on account of that badge he wears. But I tell ya, there's a lot more to bein' a man than just followin' the law.
There's a certain code in this world that any righteous individual should live by. And the law has nothin' to do with that.
The guy's prints were found on the shotgun. That seems pretty iron clad right there. But I'd be lyin' if I said I hadn't ended up in a few scrapes where my gun was in the other guy's hands.
Point is, he says he owns the gun. 'Course his prints are on it. Doesn't mean he was the one who shot it.
I don't leave home without packin'. Excludin' here, of course. I'm sure the bailiff wouldn't take too kindly to that.
Most people in this world got far more than they need. And then they somehow find a way to think they need even more.

text: Let's get this show on the road, then.
I suppose we should talk about that shotgun they say he used to kill the girl.
Personally, I don't buy it. The persecution says that he must have bought the gun recently and for this specific task. But he says he owned it for years beforehand.
Well hold on there. We don't know for sure it was him that fired it.
His prints were on the gun because it was his gun. He said he had owned it for years.
Just 'cause his prints are on the gun doesn't mean he was the one who shot it at the scene of the crime. Maybe the real killer used gloves.
He had no record of buying the gun because he bought it at a gun show. I can't figure the last time I've seen a seller at a gun show print out a receipt. It's all cash and no questions asked.
So what? It's not on him to prove he owned it. It's on the prosecution to prove he bought it recently.
It's possible someone else shot the woman and saw their way clear to puttin' on gloves before they did it.
I'm not sure 'bout that. I don't think the defense ever brought it up.
You're talkin' as if he's already been found guilty. Last I checked, we're here to determine his guilt, not sit around askin' "why would someone do such a thing".
I just don't understand how you can think like that.
Big deal. It looks bad, but I've seen worse and I've gotten worse.
The way that guy talked on the stand, it was like he had just gotten back from Vietnam. He probably deserved to get his lights knocked out for once.
Is there any way we could just not charge him for the assault?
I hardly believed it either. He's a real scrawny guy, isn't he?
